reviewText: "Shuai Jiao Kung Fu Wrestling" with Dr. Yang, Jwing-Ming  is described on the cover as Fundamental Defense Techniques and Throws, takedowns and grappling skills for short-range fighting.  This disk is that, but so much more.  Like many YMAA titles from Dr. Yang, this program provides a tremendous wealth of information.  It is over three hours of explanation and instruction, covering 27 different Shuai Jiao techniques.  The DVD is an excellent resource for any martial artist wanting to better understand and learn Shuai Jiao, Kung Fu Wrestling.The program begins with Dr. Yang in front of a white board where he explains basic concepts needed to better understand the material on this DVD.  He explains the Shuai Jiao is primarily used for defense and is used to take down your opponent.  He explains the relationship between Shai Jiao and kicking, punching, and chin na techniques.  From there he goes into a short history of Shai Jiao, and where the techniques from this program come from.  He then covers basic concepts such as left and right, high and low, and so forth.  Good explanation of leverage and its use.  He does bring in a student to help illustrate these concepts.  I'd encourage a viewer to watch this "lecture" section of the program more than once.  These principles are very important and I applaud Dr. Yang for putting them on the DVD before jumping into the technique instruction.This first part only takes 15 minutes.  Next come Basic Drills.  In this section, Dr. Yang introduces a few basic drills to help your learning and training.  He brings out students to help demonstrate these drills.  They include the leg bump, hook backward, hook forward, carry backward, pull carry, sweep, hand intercept.  These are important to safely intercept, repel, and neutralize incoming strikes.  The end of this second section is around the forty-three minute mark.Part three of the DVD is the basic Shuai Jiao Techniques.  As I stated above, there are twenty-seven techniques presented.  What I really like about Dr. Yang's DVD is that he does not just show the technique and go on to the next.  He provides detailed instruction, and has his students perform each movement.  He then steps in and points out details and corrects mistakes.  If takes him over two hours to cover these twenty-seven techniques because of the detailed instruction.  The only thing better would be to attend a live class or seminar.The techniques themselves are primarily throws and takedowns.  They are stand up techniques to put your opponent on the ground with you still standing.  This is not a program of ground grappling like many think of with wrestling.  It is not wrestling with both people grappling on the ground.  It was very similar to my primary style Hapkido, where we put people to the ground while remaining standing.While the techniques are from a Chinese art, martial artists from other styles will be able to incorporate the techniques into their training as well.  I noticed a number of techniques similar to those in my Hapkido curriculum.  I enjoyed seeing how Dr. Yang performed and explained them.Overall, this is another outstanding program from Dr. Yang and YMAA.  If you are looking for detailed explanation on putting a person to the ground with sweeps, throws, and joint-locks, this is a DVD that contains that and much more.  It's an excellent addition to anyone's martial art library.Reviewed by Alain Burrese, J.D., author of the DVD Hapkido Hoshinsul.
summary: Detailed Program on Throws and Takedowns
Title: N/A

reviewText: This single disc, 180 minute instructionally dense DVD, created by Dr. Yang, offers the viewer a set of the basic martial kinetic principles and concepts needed to successfully engage in the activity of throwing or taking down a human adversary.  These principles, however extend beyond just a grappling affair.The video begins with a brief explanation of the four main fighting categories within traditional Chinese martial disciplines, followed with a short dissertation of the Chinese historical context of Chinese wrestling's evolution.Once the viewer has the proper cultural context of Shuai Jiao, Dr. Yang provides a breakdown of the fundamental concepts of leverage through three dimensional time and space, as well as ther essential physical principles of Shuai Jiao, including explanations and demonstrations of how these universal principles are applied.We find how the push-pull actions create a kind of two-way movement: left and right, high and low, forward and rearward, which generates the kind of controlling leverage needed to break an adversary's balance for a proficient takedown.  We see how we can defensively pull a push and defensively push the pull--how pulling a pull sets up our push; how pushing the push sets up our pulling, all in order to destroy the adversary's balance, base and power for a smooth takedown.We learn about the importance of occupying the adversary's center with our own, and how entering into the enemy's space, sticking to him, through proper positioning and forward movement to the adversary's attacks, affords us the kind of control we need to over take this opponent.While Dr. Yang demonstrates 27 different individual techniques for taking a standing adversary down to the ground, along with subsequent variations for these techniques, what Dr. Yang also explains throughout the disc's instruction are all the martial kinetic principles that allow the techniques to work, and from which the individual applications sprout.The detail with which Dr. Yang explains the technical essence of the applications can be extrapolated into any martial discipline.  When one is able to gain a full understanding of these physical principles, such wisdom will help the serious practitioner toward a deeper understanding in any human movement deployment in his or her martial practices.The viewer will gain an opportunity on how to manipulate human balance, posture, positioning, dynamic entry, and applications of leverage properly as these apply to keeping him or herself strong and balance when applied against an adversary.The organization of the video's materials is easy to follow, with subtitles available to more thoroughly grasp the data being explained, adding to the production level of this DVD, which is already top quality.Dr. Yang uses three assistants, which provide the viewer a good visualization of the techniques performed at various levels of expertise, within the parameters set forth through using these different body-builds.  Such human diversity when observing the execution of the techniques, is extremely important in obtaining a better working grasp of how the physical principles are applied, regardless of the different assistants engaging the techniques.  In addition we are able to see where mistakes are made, and how these mistakes can be corrected via the expert eye of Dr. Yang, explaining how to improve performance of the physical expression of the kinetic principles responsible for making the techniques work.I personally find the greatest value of this Shuai Jiao DVD to be in the thoroughness of Dr. Yang's explanation of very important key physical principles of martial kinetics--human combative movements.  That these principles are clearly defined and demonstrated for the viewer, offers a wealth of information in how to move one's body powerfully and smoothly, not just for the technical intricacies demanded for successful wrestling takedowns, but for moving the body with power and grace in any martial arts pursuit.  From this deeper comprehension of these physical martial principles, many techniques can be derived, not just the 27 examples provided in this video.Overall, I genuinely enjoyed this DVD, and believe it will benefit anyone in any martial endeavor who seriously wants a more complete understanding of defensive human movement, utilizing the concepts and principles of Shuai Jiao.Rev. Arthur Bodhi Chenevey, RM, DDHikaze Learning Corner/Diversified Combat Arts and SciencesWooster OH
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is an excellent instructional DVD on Chinese Wrestling fundamentals.(Chinese wrestling is not wrestling on the ground, but is throwing or otherwise causing the one's opponent to go to the ground to damage them in the fall.)  Dr Yang explains that Shuai Jiao is for defending and countering to hitting and kicking attacks.  In this case the best throws are the ones that incapacitate the attacker.Dr. Yang has developed a very good formula for instructional DVDs, that he applies in this DVD.He does a short lecture on the subject.  And then he leads into the techniques.For the techniques:He does a short explanation.He then demonstrates the technique on a student, and explaining what he is doing as he demonstrates the technique.He then has 2 or more students (in this DVD 3 students) take turns demonstrating the technique 4 or 6 times.  This presents the viewer with common mistakes made and helps with knowing with what to watch out for.While the students are demonstrating the technique he points out and corrects their their technique.  And explains some of the finer points.This DVD covers the basics to get started in Shuai Jiao, except for one aspect.  This DVD does not cover fall breaking techniques, such as rolls or slapping the mat or ground to break the momentum of the fall and to protect your self.  But it is still worth purchasing.  Thus you should get another DVD or book to learn about break falls to protect yourself from damage during practice.This DVD is of very high production with clear audio and well angled camera shots. The DVD menus are well thought out and implemented.This is a good video for the person that is first time learning Chinese Wrestling (other than not covering break falls).Among the leg techniques covered are bump (a method of pressing against the back of the opponent thigh to upset their balance), hook, pull with foot, and slide.  And setup, pulling and pushing techniques are covered with the hands.  These are presented as the basics of principles with the expectation that a dedicated student with practice will be able to go on and develop more techniques.
summary: Excellent instructional DVD on Chinese Wrestling fundamentals.
Title: N/A

reviewText: For those unfamiliar with the subject of the video, Shuai Jiao is the Chinese art of takedowns and throws.  In many ways, it's like Judo with all of the niceness removed.  The goal isn't to throw the opponent onto his or her back.  It's to knock them down - period.  As such, the concepts of Shuai Jiao are extremely useful in the context of practical self-defense, and this video is a great introduction for anyone wanting to improve their skills in this realm.This video begins with a discussion of the history of Shuai Jiao and its place in the traditional Chinese Martial Arts.  Specifically, Dr. Yang discusses how Shuai Jiao is primarily designed to combat striking attacks (ti and da), while the fourth component of the traditional Chinese Martial Arts, Chin Na, focuses on neutralizing Shuai Jiao - Specifically, what to do after someone has grabbed you.  Completing the circle, striking is the main counter to Chin Na joint locks.  This piece really puts everything into context and also provides a nice discussion of what skills are necessary to becoming a complete martial artist.After this introduction, Dr. Yang proceeds to demonstrate some basic concepts (hooking, sliding, etc.) and then follows those with twenty-seven Shuai Jiao techniques taken from White Crane, Long Fist, and Taiji.  It's important to realize, though, that even though all of the techniques were derived from these three styles, I believe that almost any martial artist will be able to find techniques here that they can recognize from their art of choice, either within their forms, as part of their supplemental training, or from other sources.  Therefore, the usefulness of this video is quite broad-based and wide-ranging.As is typical in Dr. Yang's videos, each technique presented is first performed by Dr. Yang and is then demonstrated by a few of his students.  The purpose of the student demonstrations is for Dr. Yang to correct their mistakes, thus giving the viewer insight into common errors to watch for in their own training.  Most of the time, this is an extremely effective tool.  However, there were a few points in this video that I felt a bit sorry for the student demonstrators, as they did not seem familiar enough with the techniques to perform them at a reasonable level of proficiency.  This was a minor point, though, and did not distract from my enjoyment of the disc.As a final note, the production values of the video were top notch, as I've come to expect from any YMAA production.  Overall, this video was excellent, and I highly recommend it to anyone either looking to explore the art of takedowns or interested in becoming more well rounded in the martial arts.
summary: An Excellent Introduction to Shuai Jiao

reviewText: I concur with the majority of reviewers here--this IS a 5 Star video!  And while I can't add much to what has already been said about the content and production quality, I CAN say that I enjoyed it immensely and learned a lot about Shuai Jiao as well.  Think about it--you get approximately three hours of great information and instruction from Dr. Yang, Jwing-Ming--one of the best martial arts teachers in the world--for less than $40.00.  What are you waiting for?  Buy this DVD!

reviewText: Shuai Jiao is the Chinese martial art of throwing, grappling and takedowns, and is very similar to Japanese Judo. However, unlike Judo, Shuai Jiao does not make an effort to throw their opponent onto their back in order for them to land with some semblance of control. Instead, Shuai Jiao practitioners simply throw their opponent in order to hurt them and end the confrontation then and there. You gotta love that! This makes it very applicable to those of us that study the self-defense and combative styles, such as; Krav Maga.Dr. Yang continues his impeccable teaching method in this DVD and try as I might, I simply can't really find anything negative at all in his presentation or technique. Not that I expect him to, nor am I looking for the negative, I am just so impressed with Dr. Yang's books and DVD's that I have found myself trying to find something to complain about just to stir things up a bit, but alas, I am unable to.KUDO's to Dr. Yang and YMAA for once again making an excellent product.Shawn KovacichCreator of numerous books and DVD's.
summary: Throwing and Grappling in the Chinese Martial Arts
Title: N/A

reviewText: In one of his newest DVDs, Dr. Yang and his students give a great introduction to Shuai Jiao, or Chinese wrestling.  Of the four main categories of traditional Chinese martial arts, shuai jiao is probably one of  the most practiced in Chinese schools, yet most poorly explored and understood in the western hemisphere.  Kung Fu practitioners who are not versed in some throwing techniques are missing a key component of their art as shuai jiao techniques were developed as a response to strikes. Here Dr. Yang gives a brief historical introduction of the art, as well as demonstrations of over two dozen effective throwing techniques including common mistakes.As another reviewer mentioned, this DVD provides just an overview of shuai jiao and demonstration of many of possibly hundreds of techniques.  It is not an in-depth analysis of the fine details required to make the viewer an "expert" in the techniques presented.  However, any practitioner of other throwing arts such as judo may gain some insight and deeper understanding of the techniques presented or find some analogy to techniques already in their repertoire.Viewers who enjoy this DVD should also enjoy other YMAA publications:  Chinese Fast Wrestling by Liang, Shou-Yu, Taiji Wrestling by Yang, Jwing-Ming, and Advanced Practical Chin-Na In Depth, by Yang, Jwing-Ming.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really had no intentions of getting this DVD but decided to get it anyway.  I have been a wrestler or coach for 14 years but Shuai Jiao is not the same thing.  This in no way resembles western style wrestling.  What it is, is, a sneaky way to take your opponent down.  Dr. Yang has the JD Power & Associates Instructional DVD award as far as I am concerned.  He is not only a teacher but an educator.  In his own way Dr. Yang is teaching us the real skills of Gong fu.  Whithout which you cannot properly fight nor defend yourself.Shuai jiao teaches you the skills to fight back on your own terms, the movements to control your opponents body or the ability to put a person into an excrutiating split for trying to hit you. Dr. Yang in this dvd gives you the history and the background of the techniques he is about to teach you so that when he demonstrates, you will have a better idea of what he is doing.  He uses his students well.  He knows they will not always do the techniques correctly so this is an opportunity for him to point out and then correct some of the mistakes you will encounter.  He gives you the where, why and how of the technique. Just watching him and his students, you can see why the techniques are working for him and why his students are having difficulty in making the technique work.  It's a good comparison.I stumbled on some of these techniues while training, experimenting and watching old kung fu movies on the weekend.  It's a lot more fun watching kung fu movies now that I know a little more of what they are doing and how.Shuai jiao is the Owww factor.  Your opponent will have to decide if the punishement was worth tangling with you.
Title: N/A
